Last week, two Asian-American standup comics from New York released a video titled “ Ghost in the Shell PSA,” which they say aim to show the effects of whitewashing people of color out of their own stories. Video available at: https://youtube.com/watch?v=0Ll7gt0meuU . youtube.com ID: 10670116 3. In the video created by 26-year-old Jes Tom and 28-year-old Chewy May, a young Asian girl is seen entering a comic shop and rifling through the piles of comic books, but none of the lead characters are women of color. View this image › 
youtube.com ID: 10670694 4. She finally stumbles on a copy of Ghost in the Shell and starts to smile, before proceeding to buy the comic. View this image › 
youtube.com ID: 10671189 5. The video then fast forwards to when the girl is grown and walking along a street in New York, where she sees a poster for the Ghost In The Shell live-action adaptation. View this image › 
youtube.com ID: 10671205 6. Tom – who appears in the video as the older version of the young girl – told BuzzFeed News that the video was inspired by a Facebook post she wrote about the consequences of whitewashing people of color out of their own stories after she watched the Ghost In The Shell teaser last year. View this image › 
youtube.com May then saw the post and reached out with the idea of a short film “about a young Asian girl yearning to see herself represented in media, and having that representation taken away from her.”
ID: 10671278 7. “Whitewashing a superhero character tells little girls of color that they cannot be superheroes, and it hurts,” May told BuzzFeed News. View this image › 
youtube.com “Whitewashing Asian people out of stories created for and by and about us makes it hard for other people to see us as full, dimensional people,” Tom added.
